awd_titl_txt: Hybrid Halide Perovskite Materials for Photocatalytic Carbon-Carbon Bond Formation
awd_abstract_narration:
Natural photosynthesis in plants stores the energy of sunlight in new carbon-carbon bonds formed from carbon dioxide. One of the grand challenges of the 21st century is to figure out how to accomplish similar chemical reactions with man-made materials known as photocatalysts. Efficient photocatalysts use low cost and abundant molecules like carbon dioxide and methane for the light-driven production of valuable organic chemicals. Scientists have been trying to develop photocatalysts using metals such as iridium or ruthenium. However, these and many of the other materials currently under examination perform poorly as photocatalysts, are expensive, are not abundant on Earth, and/or are difficult to recycle. Dr. Yong Yan of the New Jersey Institute of Technology is developing easy-to-process photocatalysts from the lead halide perovskites that are composed entirely of low cost and abundant elements. This project focuses on demonstrating that small particles of perovskite photocatalysts can help to efficiently form new carbon-carbon bonds. Professor Yan engages in outreach to students from economically disadvantaged areas, to under-represented minorities, and women. High school student interns synthesize some of the perovskite nanoparticles used for this project.

With funding support from the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division, Dr. Yong Yan of the New Jersey Institute of Technology is developing a novel photocatalytic approach for carbon-carbon bond formation reactions using inexpensive lead halide perovskite nanoparticles. APbX3 perovskite, where A is either methylammonium or cesium and X is a halide, has displayed the potential to be an efficient and cost-effective photovoltaic material. These perovskites also show promise for photocatalytic organic synthesis due to their simple synthesis, post-reaction processability, composition from earth-abundant elements, exceptional photophysical properties, readily tunable conduction and valence bands, and high catalytic turnover numbers. Although the instability of these perovskites towards moisture hinders their application as photovoltaics, moisture sensitivity is less of a hindrance for chemical catalysis with suitable organic solvents. This project examines the stability of perovskite nanoparticles in various organic solvents and their suitability for several carbon-carbon bond formation reactions. Band edge-tuning of perovskites is used to adjust their excited-state redox potential to optimize photocatalytic organic synthesis. High school student interns synthesize some of the perovskite nanoparticles used for this project.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The NSF-funded project entails the pioneering work to employ highly-efficient solar cell perovskite materials as the highly-efficient photocatalyst for organic synthesis with a particular focus on elusive carbon-carbon bond formation reactions. The project here provides a paradigm shift from expensive homogeneous noble-metal catalysts to heterogeneous economic materials with high catalytic reactivity, for usage in light-illuminated organic synthesis, a completely new but highly-demand research area.

The project here leads to important publications in the field, including one of the most-read and most cited works (2019-2020) on the Journal of American Chemical Society 2019 and editor's choice Nature Communications 2019.   Under this NSF support, we have successfully demonstrated that photophysical properties of perovskites already proved for photovoltaics, also should be of interest in photocatalytic organic synthesis. Because the key aspects of these two applications are both relying on charge separation and charge transfer. We further proved that, in addition to perovskite photocatalytic α-alkylation reaction, perovskites nanocrystals are also exceptional photocatalysts for many other C–C bond formations, i.e. via C–H activations, via non-noble metal based cross-couplings. Here we have successfully reached our proposed research goals to tune the perovskite and realized exceptional catalytic reactivity, for instance, using copper-doped perovskite nanocrystals for sequential charge transfer, such work was published on the Journal of American Chemical Society 2021.

The funded work here also made broader impacts by providing substantial educational and training opportunities for student researchers at SDSU, a minority serving institute. It provides direct personnel supports and indirect lab materials supports to about 30 researchers at SDSU at different levels. Undergraduate student, graduate students, and postdoctoral researchers have obtained extensive training in scientific writing, academic presentation, lab design, nanomaterials synthesis, chemical characterization skills, catalyst development, and organic synthesis. The Yan lab researchers have also been significantly benefited from this grant to attend national and international conferences for research discussions, seminars, interactions, as well as career opportunities. Broader impact for undergraduate teaching has also been achieved by re-design an undergraduate course Chem 427 Inorganic Chemistry Laboratory.  The easily accessible method for the preparation of a large scale of perovskite nanocrystal demonstrates a perfect model for a teaching class at SDSU. Undergraduate students with no or limited background in inorganic chemistry research, now gain the hand-on experience to successfully synthesize large quantity of high quality perovskite semiconductor materials, thus preparing these students with extra career opportunities in semiconductor-related areas.  

These funded works together change scientists’ original view on perovskites’ high-efficiency but unstable properties in solar cell field. Now its application in hydrophobic organic solvent for organic synthesis with high turnover number, implies very high stability in such organic system. Our other following works within this funded project also proved that such a catalyst is a great candidate to further employ in many other elusive chemical reactions, addressing long-term challenges in photocatalytic reaction design and development. These unique applications indeed attract attentions both in the community of materials sciences and the community of organic synthesis, and may also open a new realm to take advantage of such economic and easily-accessible hybrid materials for broader catalysis purpose. This NSF-funded project here offers particular opportunities to use renewable solar energy for complicated molecules synthesis, for instance life-saving drug development.  


Last Modified: 08/03/2023
Modified by: Yong Yan
